**Hybe Co., Ltd.**[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-7) ([Korean](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korean_language "Korean language"):하이브; stylized as **Hybe Corporation**; commonly known as simply **Hybe**) is a South Korean [multinational](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multinational_corporation "Multinational corporation") entertainment company established in 2005 by [Bang Si-hyuk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bang_Si-hyuk "Bang Si-hyuk") as **Big Hit Entertainment Co., Ltd.**

The company operates as a [record label](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Record_label "Record label"), [talent agency](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talent_agency "Talent agency"), music production company, [event management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_management "Event management") and concert production company, and music publishing house. It has multiple subsidiaries, including [Big Hit Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Hit_Music "Big Hit Music"), Belift Lab, [Source Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source_Music "Source Music"), [Pledis Entertainment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pledis_Entertainment "Pledis Entertainment"), KOZ Entertainment, and ADOR, collectively known as Hybe Labels.

History
-------

### 2005–2021: Big Hit Entertainment Co., Ltd.

Big Hit Entertainment was founded on February 1, 2005,[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-8) and signed the vocal trio [8Eight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/8Eight "8Eight") in 2007.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:0-9) In 2010, the company signed a contract with [JYP Entertainment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JYP_Entertainment "JYP Entertainment") to jointly manage the boy group [2AM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2AM_(band) "2AM (band)").[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:2-10) That year, Bang Si-hyuk signed [RM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RM_(rapper) "RM (rapper)") as the first member of [BTS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BTS "BTS") and launched nationwide auditions to recruit other members for the group.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-11) BTS made their debut under Big Hit on June 13, 2013.[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-12)

In 2012, the company signed [Lim Jeong-hee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lim_Jeong-hee "Lim Jeong-hee"),[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:1-13) and formed the girl group [Glam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GLAM_(band) "GLAM (band)") as a collaboration with [Source Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source_Music "Source Music").[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-14) The group was active until 2014, when it was disbanded due to a controversy involving one of its members Kim Da-hee. Kim was sentenced to prison after being found guilty of blackmailing actor [Lee Byung-hun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Byung-hun "Lee Byung-hun").[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-15)[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-16)[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-17)

Following the end of the joint contract between Big Hit and JYP in April 2014, three members of 2AM returned to JYP. [Lee Chang-min](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Chang-min_(singer) "Lee Chang-min (singer)") remained with Big Hit to continue with his solo career and as part of the duo [Homme](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homme_(band) "Homme (band)").[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:2-10) 8Eight disbanded later that year, after Baek Chan and Joo Hee's contracts with Big Hit ended.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:0-9)

In May 2015, Lim parted ways with the agency, following the expiration of her three-year contract,[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:1-13) and [Signal Entertainment Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signal_Entertainment_Group "Signal Entertainment Group"), a [KOSDAQ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KOSDAQ "KOSDAQ")-listed company specializing in artist management and television production, acquired Big Hit through a [KR₩](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korean_won "South Korean won")6 billion [convertible bond](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convertible_bond "Convertible bond").[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-edaily-18) In early 2016, Big Hit ended their stake relationship with Signal and made a full settlement of the bonds.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-19)[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-20)

In February 2018, Homme disbanded after member Changmin's contract ended. He left the company to start his own agency, while [Lee Hyun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Hyun "Lee Hyun") continued on as a solo artist.[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Lee_Hyun_now_solo-21) In August, Big Hit and [CJ ENM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CJ_ENM_Entertainment_Division "CJ ENM Entertainment Division") released information stating plans to create a joint entertainment agency, with ownership split 52% to the latter and 48% to the former.[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-22)[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-23) Filed under the name Belift Lab, the agency debuted its first boy group [Enhypen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enhypen "Enhypen") in November 2020.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-24) In October, BTS renewed and extended their contract with the agency for seven more years.[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-25) Big Hit was voted Best Investment Company of the Year at the 2018 Korea VC Awards in December.[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-26)

Big Hit debuted its second male group, [Tomorrow X Together](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TXT_(band) "TXT (band)") (TXT), in March 2019.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-27) Also that month, former [CBO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_business_officer "Chief business officer") Lenzo Yoon was appointed co-CEO alongside Bang.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-28) Yoon would focus on the business components of the company. while Bang's focus would be on creative production.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-29) In July 2019, the company acquired [Source Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source_Music "Source Music"),[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-30) and in August, the video game firm Superb.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-31) Thanks to the [Weverse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weverse "Weverse") and Weverse Shop[[c]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-33) apps developed by its subsidiary beNX, Big Hit was named the fourth most innovative company of 2020 worldwide by _[Fast Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast\_Company "Fast Company")_.[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-34)

In May 2020, Big Hit became the majority shareholder of [Pledis Entertainment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pledis_Entertainment "Pledis Entertainment"). The label would retain its independence; however, its artists would now receive greater financial support and global promotions.[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-35) The [Fair Trade Commission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fair_Trade_Commission_(South_Korea) "Fair Trade Commission (South Korea)") (KFTC) approved the acquisition in October.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-36) Big Hit acquired KOZ Entertainment, a record label founded by rapper [Zico](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zico_(rapper) "Zico (rapper)"), the following month.[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Benjamin-37)

In January 2021, news media reported that Big Hit and beNX had invested a combined ₩70 billion (US$63 million) in [YG Plus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YG_Plus "YG Plus"), acquiring a 17.9% stake in the company in a merchandising and distribution deal that would see YG Plus' artists join the Weverse social media and shop platforms.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-38)[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-39)[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-40)[Naver Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naver_Corporation "Naver Corporation") later invested ₩354.8 billion ($321 million) in beNX, acquiring 49% of the subsidiary. In return, it transferred its [V Live](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V_Live "V Live") video streaming service to the latter for the development of a new integrated fan community platform. BeNX was eventually renamed Weverse Company Inc. as a result of the deal with Naver.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-KJAD_Naver_benx-41) The merger was approved by the KFTC in May.[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-42) On February 17, Big Hit and [Universal Music Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Music_Group "Universal Music Group") (UMG) announced a strategic partnership between the two companies to collaborate on various music and technology-related endeavors.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-43) At the forefront of the partnership was a joint venture between Big Hit and [Geffen Records](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interscope_Geffen_A%26M_Records "Interscope Geffen A&M Records"), a UMG flagship label, that will debut a global boy group through a new, [Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles")-based label following a global audition program set to air in 2022. Big Hit would be responsible for selecting and training the artists, while UMG would be in charge of music production, global distribution, and marketing.[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-44) Additionally, other UMG artists, including [Yungblud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yungblud "Yungblud"), were set to join Weverse, already home to [Gracie Abrams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gracie_Abrams "Gracie Abrams"), [New Hope Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Hope_Club "New Hope Club"), and Alexander 23.[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-45) On February 25, Big Hit announced a ₩4 billion ($3.6 million) investment in a Korea-based AI company, Supertone, that specializes in creating hyper-realistic voices using technology.[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-46)

### 2021–present: Hybe Corporation, expansions, and investigations

Big Hit announced its rebranding into an entertainment lifestyle platform company under the name Hybe Corporation in March 2021.[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-47) The company underwent a complete organizational restructuring, which also saw the recording and management arm of Big Hit Entertainment spun off into an independent label named [Big Hit Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Hit_Music "Big Hit Music") under Hybe's new Labels division. The renaming was approved at a shareholders meeting on March 30.[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-hybe_presentation-48)[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-49) The company relocated to its new headquarters in the Yongsan Trade Center in [Yongsan District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yongsan_District "Yongsan District") on March 22,[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-hybe_presentation-48)[[1]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-yongsan-3) and the rebrand went into effect on March 31.[[47]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-50) Hybe acquired [Scooter Braun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scooter_Braun "Scooter Braun")'s Ithaca Holdings and all its properties, including SB Projects[[d]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-51) and [Big Machine Label Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Machine_Records#Imprints "Big Machine Records"), through its subsidiary Hybe America[[e]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Hybe_America-52) in April.[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Variety_Ithaca-53)[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-54) The corporation invested $950 million (₩1.07 trillion) into the America branch to finance the buyout;[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-55) $1.05 billion was paid to Ithaca shareholders and bondholders.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-56) BH Odyssey Merger Sub, a newly created subsidiary of Hybe America, facilitated the acquisition, and was later dissolved after the deal's finalization.[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-KJAD_Ithaca-57)[[53]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-58) The Carlyle Group, a minority shareholder and original investor, sold its stake in Ithaca as part of the deal. Braun joined Hybe's board, while [Scott Borchetta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Borchetta "Scott Borchetta") retained his position as CEO of Big Machine.[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Variety_Ithaca-53)[[54]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-59) That same month, _[Time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time\_(magazine) "Time (magazine)")_ named Hybe one of the "100 Most Influential Companies of 2021", under the "Pioneers" section.[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-60)

Japanese streaming platform [Showroom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showroom_(streaming_service) "Showroom (streaming service)") announced a business and capital partnership with Hybe in May 2021 to improve its domestic services and expand access to Japanese content in South Korea, the United States, and globally.[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-61)[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-62) Hybe was added to the [MSCI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MSCI "MSCI") Korea index on May 12, and the index updated on May 28.[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-63) Following a second organizational restructuring, Bang resigned as CEO on July 1 to return his focus to music production. He was replaced by Park Ji-won but retained his position as chairman of the board of directors.[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Bang_resigns_CEO-64)[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-BSH_resign_MBW-65) In November, Hybe entered into an equity-based partnership with Korean [fintech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Financial_technology "Financial technology") company Dunamu to develop a joint venture [NFT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-fungible_token "Non-fungible token") business for the creation of digital assets.[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-66)[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Pulse-67) It acquired a 2.6% stake in the company for ₩500 billion ($423.8 million), while Dunamu received a 5.6% stake in Hybe for ₩700 billion ($590 million).[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Pulse-67)[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-68) On November 11, Hybe won a [Red Dot Design Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Dot "Red Dot") in the Brands & Communication Design category at the 2021 Red Dot Design Awards for its new [corporate identity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporate_identity "Corporate identity") (CI) design.[[f]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-69)[[64]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-70) The establishment of a new music label, ADOR,[[g]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-72) was announced on November 12. [Chief Brand Officer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_brand_officer "Chief brand officer") (CBO) [Min Hee-jin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Min_Hee-jin "Min Hee-jin") was appointed as its CEO and tasked with overseeing the management of the label's first girl group,[[h]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-73) later announced as [NewJeans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewJeans "NewJeans"), which debuted in July 2022.[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-74)

In January 2022, Hybe published a series of "original stories" featuring boy groups BTS, Enhypen, and Tomorrow X Together in collaboration with [Webtoon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Webtoon_(publisher) "Webtoon (publisher)") and [Wattpad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wattpad "Wattpad") as part of a planned IP expansion.[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-75) The BTS comic alone earned over 15 million views within two days of release and was the highest-viewed title ever launched by Webtoon.[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-76) In March, _Fast Company_ named Hybe the 11th most innovative company of the year globally on its annual top-50 list[[69]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-77)—ranking first in the Media category[[70]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-78)—while _Time_ included Hybe on its 100 Most Influential Companies list for a second consecutive year.[[71]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-79) The company topped the "Leaders" category and was dubbed "The Pop Powerhouse" by the outlet for its acquisitions, expansion into the digital frontier, and transformative strides in the music industry during the pandemic era.[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-80)[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-81) The following month, Hybe won an [iF Product Design Award](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IF_Product_Design_Award "IF Product Design Award") for "Company Branding" in the Communication category at the [International Forum Design Awards](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Forum_Design "International Forum Design") held in Germany.[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-82) Hybe signed a multi-year deal with [The Walt Disney Company Asia Pacific](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_assets_owned_by_The_Walt_Disney_Company#The_Walt_Disney_Company_Asia_Pacific "List of assets owned by The Walt Disney Company") in July 2022 to provide content showcasing the Korean music and entertainment industries to a global market. Five programs will be available worldwide on [Disney+](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disney%2B "Disney+") and other Disney streaming platforms—a [4K](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4K_resolution "4K resolution") cinematic film of BTS' [Permission to Dance on Stage concert in Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Permission_to_Dance_on_Stage#Film "Permission to Dance on Stage"); _[In the Soop: Friendcation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In\_the\_Soop:\_Friendcation "In the Soop: Friendcation")_; and _BTS Monuments: Beyond the Star_, a [docuseries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_documentary "Television documentary") of BTS' history from debut to present set to premiere in 2023. Additional content featuring other Hybe artists will also be released.[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-83)[[76]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-84)

Hybe became the largest shareholder of [SM Entertainment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SM_Entertainment "SM Entertainment") in February 2023, after it acquired founder [Lee Soo-man](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Soo-man "Lee Soo-man")'s 14.8% stake in the company for approximately ₩422.8 billion.[[77]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-85) The company subsequently acquired [Galaxia SM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxia_SM "Galaxia SM")'s 1% stake on March 3.[[78]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-86) On March 12, Hybe announced that they no longer planned to own the majority stakes of SM Entertainment, said that the bidding war with [Kakao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kakao "Kakao") could "damage shareholder value."[[79]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-87) On March 24, Hybe announced that it will sell its entire stake in SM Entertainment to Kakao by accepting its tender offer launched by Kakao.[[80]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-88) However, on March 28, Hybe instead sold half of its stakes in SM to Kakao, leaving it only for 8.81%.[[81]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-89) On May 27, 2025, Hybe announced it would sell all of its shares in SM Entertainment to [Tencent Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tencent_Music "Tencent Music").[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-90)[[83]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-91)[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-92)

On May 23, Hybe signed a music distribution deal with Chinese streaming platform, [Tencent Music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tencent_Music "Tencent Music").[[85]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-93)

On August 10, Hybe announced its acquisition of the remaining 51.5% stake from CJ ENM in Belift Lab, making it as a wholly-owned subsidiary.[[86]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-hybefully-94)[[87]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-enhypenbacker-95)

In November, Hybe confirmed the establishment of its [Latin music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_music "Latin music") division, Hybe Latin America, based in [Mexico City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City"), Los Angeles, and Miami.[_[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation\_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

On August 27, 2024, Min was removed from her role as CEO of ADOR but remained on the company's board of directors and continued producing for NewJeans. Kim Ju-young, Hybe's Chief Human Resources Officer and a member of the board, assumed the position of ADOR's CEO. Min objected this decision, describing her as a "grave violation of the shareholders' agreement."[[88]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-96)

In December, it was revealed that the Financial Supervisory Service (FSS) was investigating whether Chairman Bang Si-hyuk had entered into secret shareholder agreements with STIC Investments, Estone Equity Partners, and New Main Equity without informing other shareholders or the financial regulator. These agreements allegedly allowed him to financially benefit misleading other shareholders into believing that Hybe would not pursue an IPO.[[89]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-97) On May 28, 2025, the FSS referred Bang Si-hyuk to the prosecution after concluding that the investigation met the threshold for charges.[[90]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-98) The following day, searched Hybe's headquarters connection with allegations of insider trading by an employee who allegedly used confidential information to profit from acquiring shares in YG Plus, based on prior of Hybe's planned investment in the company in July 2021.[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-99)

On May 28, 2025, Hybe announced the sale of Big Machine Rock to Gebbia Media,[[92]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-100) followed the next day by the announcement of establishing a Chinese subsidiary.[[93]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-101)[[94]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-102)[[95]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-103)

Company value and investments
-----------------------------

Big Hit Entertainment initially operated as a private company with Bang Si-hyuk as the largest shareholder of its stock.[[96]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:3-104) In March 2017, the Korean mobile gaming company [Netmarble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netmarble_Games "Netmarble Games") acquired the second largest percentage of the company, paying a reported ₩201.4 billion ($191.8 million) for 25.71%[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-105)—its CEO Bang Joon-hyuk, and Bang Si-hyuk are relatives.[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-106) In October 2018, private investment firm [STIC Investments](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/STIC_Investments "STIC Investments") received an undisclosed share of Big Hit for an investment of roughly ₩104 billion ($93 million).[[99]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-107)

In 2007, Big Hit had four employees and was near bankruptcy, but Bang was able to keep the company afloat after the local success of [8Eight](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/8Eight "8Eight")'s _Without a Heart_ in 2009.[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-108) Over the years, its value rose in tandem with the increasing global popularity of its first boy group BTS.[[101]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-109) In March 2018, Big Hit's earnings were publicized for the first time. The company reported revenue of ₩92.4 billion ($82 million) and operating profit of ₩32.5 billion ($29 million) for 2017.[[102]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-110)[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-theinvestor.co.kr-111) Initial estimates valued Big Hit at up to ₩700 billion ($624 million) if entered into an [IPO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Initial_public_offering "Initial public offering") that very month, making CEO Bang the richest in the South Korean entertainment business due to his large shareholding position, and leaving him with personal ownership value of roughly ₩350 billion ($314 million).[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-112) By October 2018, the company was valued at more than ₩1 trillion.[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-theinvestor.co.kr-111)

Big Hit's success has been attributed to its innovative management style, more like an IT company than an entertainment company, which has become the new standard in the K-pop industry; it includes a wide usage of [social media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media "Social media") to capture people's interest and transform it into sales, the creation of artist-related multimedia content, and the full use of [fandom](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fandom "Fandom") energy.[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-113)[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-114) Financials published in March 2019 for 2018, showed a 132% increase in sales compared to 2017, with Big Hit making approximately ₩214.2 billion ($189.38 million). Operating profit rose 97% to ₩64.1 billion ($56.72 million), while net profit rose 105% to ₩50.2 billion ($44.41 million).[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-115) By June 2019, the company was valued between ₩1.28–2.22 trillion.[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-116) As of March 2020, its total value was roughly ₩6 trillion ($5 billion).[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-117) Big Hit commenced plans to go public on May 21, and applied for a pre-IPO consultation with the [Korea Exchange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Korea_Exchange "Korea Exchange"). This is required under South Korean law before a company can file paperwork for an IPO.[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-118) One week later, the company filed for a preliminary review of their planned IPO.[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-119) On October 15, Big Hit was listed in the [KOSPI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KOSPI "KOSPI") index and began trading stocks.[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-120)[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-121)

Per the company's 2020 annual report, its first since going public, Big Hit recorded net income of ₩86.2 billion ($77.6 million), a 19.1% increase compared to 2019's ₩72.4 billion.[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-yonhap-122) Operating profit rose 44.3% to ₩142.4 billion, while sales increased 35.6% to ₩796.3 billion[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-yonhap-122)—bolstered in part by album revenue and various acquisitions—with the company experiencing its best quarterly performance yet in the fourth quarter of 2020.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-BH_2020-123) Though concert revenue decreased in the wake of the [COVID-19 pandemic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_South_Korea "COVID-19 pandemic in South Korea"), merchandise, fan-club, and online-content revenue increased 53%, 71%, and 66%, respectively.[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-BH_2020-123)[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-124) In 2021, Big Hit became the first South Korean music agency to surpass the ₩1 trillion ($838 million) benchmark. It recorded annual revenue of ₩1.2 trillion, operating profit of ₩190.3 billion, and net income of ₩141 billion ($118 million).[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-125)[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-126)

Divisions and subsidiaries
--------------------------

### Hybe HQ

Hybe HQ is a wholly owned subsidiary of Hybe Corporation. The company comprises three divisions: Hybe Labels, Hybe Solutions, and Hybe Platforms. Under each division are wholly or partially owned subsidiaries of its parent corporation.[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-MBW_Hybe_presentation-127)[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-128)

#### Solutions

The "solutions" division is made up of specialized business units for video content, [IP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intellectual_property "Intellectual property"), learning, and games. Secondary and tertiary businesses are created based on the creative output of each label.[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-MBW_Hybe_presentation-127) In May 2021, Hybe Edu signed a business agreement with the International Korean Language Education Foundation (IKLEF) to develop Korean-language textbooks for distribution to overseas elementary and secondary schools through the Ministry of Education beginning in 2022. Various other online and offline content will also be created using BTS IP in response to an increasing demand for Korean-language education in foreign countries.[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-137) On July 2, 2021, it was announced that Hybe Solutions subsidiaries Hybe 360 and Hybe IP had been dissolved and merged into Hybe Corporation.[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-138)

*   Hybe Edu[[j]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-139)

#### Platforms

This is the technology division. It manages the social networking and entertainment platform [Weverse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weverse "Weverse"), which serves as a hub for connecting and expanding all of Hybe's contents and services.[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-MBW_Hybe_presentation-127) In May 2021, Weverse Company invested in US [startup](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Startup_company "Startup company") Fave, an [F2F](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Friend-to-friend "Friend-to-friend") platform for fandoms, as part of its plans to strengthen business opportunities in that territory.[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-140)

*   Weverse Company[[k]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-141)

### Hybe America

Prior to the rebrand, the subsidiary was known as Big Hit America. Following the rebranding, Hybe Corporation bought over all ₩1.7 trillion ($1.5 billion) of Big Hit America's shares, making it a wholly owned subsidiary under the corporation, and it became Hybe America.[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-KJAD_Ithaca-57) This was in preparation for Hybe Corporation's acquisition of Ithaca Holdings through Hybe America.[[e]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Hybe_America-52) BH Odyssey Merger Sub was created as a subsidiary of Hybe America to facilitate its buyout of Ithaca. Once finalized, Ithaca would become a subsidiary of Hybe America, and BH Odyssey would be dissolved.[[52]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-KJAD_Ithaca-57)[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Variety_Ithaca-53) The merger is assumed to have been completed in the first quarter of 2021 per quarterly earning reports published on May 14.[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-142)

In July 2021, Yoon and Braun were appointed co-CEOs of Hybe America, and jointly managed US operations. Yoon was responsible for "the localization of Hybe's K-pop business model in the US" and "oversee[ing] the training, production and marketing process through which new talent is discovered" while Braun focused "on solidifying Hybe's presence in the US music industry" and "cementing [the company's] competitiveness in the stateside market." Chief Strategy Officer (CSO) Jaesang Lee, who led the Ithaca acquisition, was made Chief Operations Officer (COO).[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-143)[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-BSH_resign_MBW-65) Plans for the launch of a new global girl group in collaboration with Geffen were announced on November 4; auditions closed on November 28.[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-NME_2021_briefing-144)[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-145) Braun became the sole CEO in January 2023,[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-146) subsequently leading the acquisition of the American entertainment company QC Media Holdings in February.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-147)

### Hybe Japan

Following Hybe's second leadership restructuring in July 2021, its Japanese subsidiaries, Hybe Solutions Japan and Hybe T&D Japan,[[l]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-148) were integrated to form a regional headquarters, Hybe Japan. The Japanese branch operates as an independent entity under CEO and former Hybe Solutions Japan CEO Han Hyun-rock.[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-149) It oversees music production, music publishing, music copyright management, artist management, and talent scouting and development,[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-HybeJapan-150) as well as facilitates the entry of other Hybe artists into the Japanese market.[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-Bang_resigns_CEO-64) Hybe Labels Japan debuted its first boy group, [&Team](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%26Team "&Team"), in December 2022.[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-151) A collaboration with [Hiroomi Tosaka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiroomi_Tosaka "Hiroomi Tosaka") of [J Soul Brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandaime_J_Soul_Brothers "Sandaime J Soul Brothers"), announced in 2021,[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-152) resulted in the creation of the girl group [Moonchild](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moonchild_(group) "Moonchild (group)"), which debuted in 2023;[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-153) Hybe Labels Japan co-produces the group with [LDH Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LDH_(company) "LDH (company)").[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-154)

### Hybe Latin America

In November, Hybe confirmed the establishment of its [Latin music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_music "Latin music") division, Hybe Latin America, based in [Mexico City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mexico_City "Mexico City"), [Los Angeles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles "Los Angeles"), and [Miami](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami "Miami"). Concurrently, they announced the appointment of Kah Jong-Hyun, former [vice president](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vice_president "Vice president") of [YG Entertainment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/YG_Entertainment "YG Entertainment"), as the [CEO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chief_executive_officer "Chief executive officer") of this division and the acquisition of the studio Exile Content.[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-157) In March 2024, Kah Jong-Hyun appointed former EMI and [Universal Music México](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_Music_M%C3%A9xico "Universal Music México") executive Fernando Grediaga as general manager of the Mexico City-based Docemil Music.[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-158) In June, it was announced that Exile Music would be changing its name to Zarpazo and would be based in Miami, in addition to the name change of its service from Exile Podcasts to Ajá Podcats.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-159)

*   Zarpazo (previously Exile Music)
*   Docemil Music

Hybe China was established on April 2, 2025.[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-160)

The Indian branch of Hybe is expected to launch in September or October 2025. The company is conducting local market research and completing the necessary procedures to establish a corporate entity.[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-161)

Controversies
-------------

### Dispute with Min Hee-jin

On April 22, 2024, Hybe requested for [Min Hee-jin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Min_Hee-jin "Min Hee-jin"), the CEO of their sub-label ADOR, to step down from her position following an [audit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Audit "Audit") of the label amidst accusations of Min attempting to make ADOR independent.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-162)[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-163) Min released a statement dismissing those claims and also accused Hybe of overlooking the similarities between [NewJeans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewJeans "NewJeans") and [Illit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illit "Illit"), a girl group that debuted in March 2024 under Hybe's sub-label Belift Lab. In her statement she accused Hybe and Belift of refusing to acknowledge the claims of [Illit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illit "Illit") plagiarizing [NewJeans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NewJeans "NewJeans")' image from music to style, which caused confusion online amongst fans.[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-164)[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-165) The value of Hybe's shares fell by 8.03% following the news.[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-166)

Hybe officially reported Min Hee-jin to the police for "breach of trust" on April 24 following evidence retrieved from the audit that she is attempting to gain management of the label. Hybe later released text messages between Min and ADOR's vice CEO listing a series of methods to take control of the label. Hybe has also stated that they plan to meet with the legal representatives of NewJeans' members to discuss providing them with psychological and emotional care to support them for a successful return in the future.[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-167)[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-168)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:4-169) It was also announced that NewJeans, who are set to release a new single in May, will carry out activities as planned.[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-170)

On April 25, seven hours after the report was filed, Min held an emergency press conference to deny the accusations against her. During the conference, she shared text messages exchanged between her, Bang Si-hyuk, and Hybe's CEO Park Ji-won, some of which included Bang mentioning groups outside of Hybe. She accused Hybe of fabricating her words and revealed that she had filed an internal report in the past because the company failed to address her concerns over their treatment of NewJeans and her as a producer, however, this was ignored by the management.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:5-171)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:4-169)[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-172) Issues regarding Hybe's leadership also came to light as Min accused Bang of trying to control all of Hybe's sub-labels and removing their uniqueness. Min also stated that she's willing to talk to either Bang or Park but they never agreed.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:5-171)[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:4-169)

Hybe requested for ADOR to organize a board meeting on April 30. If the board members refuse to attend, then a request would be filed in court to open a shareholders' meeting for the label. The company also refuted all of Min's claims, additionally stating that she should respond to the audit and promptly step down from her position.[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-:4-169)[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-173) Following a court case held on May 30, Min's injunction to stop Hybe from exercising their voting rights to dismiss her was accepted. If Hybe were to violate this and fire her, they would have to pay a compensation of [₩](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Korean_won "South Korean won")20 [billion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1,000,000,000 "1,000,000,000") ([US$](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USD "USD")17.48 million).[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-174)[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-175)

On November 20, 2024, Min resigned from all her positions (including the board internal director) at both ADOR and Hybe.[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-176)

On January 9, 2025, Chairman Park Jung-kyu of the tech company Davolink alleged in an interview that Min had made efforts to "poach" NewJeans. He also mentioned that there had been previous discussions between him and Min regarding potential investment and the possibility of NewJeans leaving ADOR to sign exclusive contracts with another company.[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-177)

### Insider trading

In June 2024, South Korean prosecutors charged three employees of Hybe subsidiaries with [insider trading](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insider_trading "Insider trading"). They were accused of selling shares in the company before BTS members announced they were taking a break on June 14, 2022. Prosecutors stated that the employees acted with prior knowledge of the announcement, enabling them to avoid losses ranging from $24,000 to more than $108,000.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-178)

### Leaked audit documents

On October 24, 2024, Hybe came under scrutiny during a [National Assembly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Assembly_(South_Korea) "National Assembly (South Korea)") audit when Representative Min Hyung-bae of the [Democratic Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_Party_(South_Korea,_2015) "Democratic Party (South Korea, 2015)") questioned the company's COO, Kim Tae-ho, about controversial internal practices. Min revealed an internal Hybe document titled "Weekly Music Industry Report," reportedly spanning around 18,000 pages, which contained derogatory remarks about K-pop idols, unverified rumors, and harsh commentary, with parts of it being leaked online after the hearing. In response, Hybe CEO Lee Jae-sang issued a public apology on October 29, explaining that the document was "a compilation of public opinions and reactions related to K-pop trends and issues," shared with a limited number of executives to analyze market and fan sentiment. He acknowledged that the content was highly inappropriate and unacceptable, adding that Hybe was "reaching out to each agency individually to offer our apologies directly." Lee also apologized to the artists under Hybe who had been criticized as a result of the document.[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-179)[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-180)[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-181)

Philanthropy
------------

On February 13, 2023, Hybe donated 500 million won through Save the Children to support the recovery of victims from [2023 Turkey–Syria earthquake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2023_Turkey%E2%80%93Syria_earthquake "2023 Turkey–Syria earthquake").[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-188)

On April 2, 2025, Hybe donated 1 billion won through [National Cultural Heritage Administration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Cultural_Heritage_Administration "National Cultural Heritage Administration") and [National Trust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_trust "National trust") for Cultural Heritage to help repair and restore national heritage damaged by [wildfires](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2025_South_Korea_wildfires "2025 South Korea wildfires") in the Ulsan, Gyeongbuk, and Gyeongnam regions.[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybe_Corporation#cite_note-189)
